title: Exploring Image Dataset Structure through Deep Feature Extraction and Dimensionality Reduction
abstract: This study explores the use of dimensionality reduction methods, focusing on Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE), to visualize image dataset information. We applied these methods to two datasets with varying class complexities: Fruits 360 (141 classes) and CIFAR-10 (10 classes). Our goal was to assess how well these techniques preserve class separations in reduced dimensions. PCA required 221 components to explain 95% of the variance in CIFAR-10 and 239 components for Fruits 360. However, PCA struggled to provide clear class separations, particularly in CIFAR-10, due to the dataset's complexity. In contrast, t-SNE demonstrated superior ability to capture non-linear relationships, yielding clearer clusters in Fruits 360 and partial separations in CIFAR-10. Although t-SNE is highly effective, it is computationally demanding and highly sensitive to hyperparameters, necessitating precise adjustments for optimal performance. Additionally, combining ResNet50 with t-SNE as a feature extractor enhanced the visualizations, particularly for CIFAR-10, where PCA was less effective. However, memory constraints arise when processing large datasets. This study highlights the strengths and limitations of PCA and t-SNE for data visualization.
